title: 109_s1987
content: The Act is titled the "Low-Income Home Energy Security Tax Act" and introduces a refundable tax credit for residential energy cost assistance under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Low-Income Home Energy Security Tax Act" introduces a tax credit for residential energy costs for individuals, capped at 33% of expenses or $300 per month. The credit is subject to income limitations based on adjusted gross income. The tax credit for residential energy costs is capped at 33% of expenses or $300 per month, subject to income limitations based on adjusted gross income. Adjusted gross income is determined without regard to certain sections. Residential energy costs include energy utility and home energy fuel expenses for the taxpayer's principal residence in the US. The credit amount is reduced by any grants received. The tax credit for residential energy costs is capped at 33% of expenses or $300 per month, subject to income limitations based on adjusted gross income. The credit amount is reduced by any grants received, including those from the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance program. The term 'principal residence' is defined as the taxpayer's residence during the taxable year, with no ownership requirement imposed. This section also applies to homeowners associations and tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations. Stockholders in cooperative housing corporations can allocate residential energy costs to individuals paying for them. Dollar amounts in subsections (a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) will be adjusted for inflation after 2005. The dollar amounts in subsection (b)(1)(A) will be adjusted for inflation after 2005, with a cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year by substituting 'calendar year 2004' for 'calendar year 1992'. Fuel price inflation adjustment is based on the CPI fuel component for October of the preceding calendar year compared to October of 2004. The CPI fuel component is defined as the fuel component of the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers. Dollar amounts in subsections (a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10 and $50, respectively. Coordination with advance payments of credit is required. The IRS will reduce the credit allowed to taxpayers by the amount paid on their behalf for energy costs. The Secretary can create regulations for this section, applicable to energy costs after enactment, ending before January 1, 2008. SEC. 7529 allows for the advance payment of credit for residential energy costs. The Secretary will establish a program to make payments to providers of residential energy on behalf of certified individuals. Payments are limited to the amount of the credit allowable under section 36. A certified individual is someone with a qualified residential energy costs credit eligibility certificate. The residential energy costs credit eligibility certificate is a written statement certified by the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance program official of the State. Information Returns section of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include this certificate. "SEC. 6050U. RETURNS RELATING TO CREDIT FOR RESIDENTIAL ENERGY COSTS." "Every person receiving payments under section 7529 for a certified individual must file a return with the IRS, including individual details and months of entitlement." Every person required to make a return under section 7529 must provide specific information to individuals, including the person's name, address, phone number, and details required for the return. This statement must be given to the individual by January 31 of the following year. Every person required to make a return under section 7529 must provide specific information to individuals by January 31 of the following year. Conforming amendments allow disclosure of return information for advance payment of credit for residential energy costs. Clerical amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifically regarding the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. Section 35 is removed and a new item is added related to the advance payment of credit for residential energy costs. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new sections related to the advance payment of credit for residential energy costs. This includes the addition of sections 7529 and 6050U to the table of sections.
